Diagnosis
	1. Transitional cell carcinoma of right ureter with liver metastases and extensive nodal disease

	Date of diagnosis
	March 2024

	Treatment aim
	Palliative

	Summary of completed treatment and relevant dates

	Surgery
	15 Mar 2024 Diagnostic right ureteroscopy and biopsy

	Radiotherapy
	Not yet commenced

	Chemotherapy
	Not yet commenced

	Clinical studies
	Molecular profiling completed - TSC2 mutation identified

	Current disease status
	Stable metastatic disease

	Current issues
	Right-sided hydronephrosis
Intermittent right flank pain
Mild peripheral edema

	Summary of consultation
	I had the pleasure of meeting [redacted name] today in our uro-oncology clinic. This 67-year-old gentleman has recently been diagnosed with advanced urothelial carcinoma of the right ureter. The diagnosis followed investigations for persistent right-sided flank pain and microscopic hematuria.

Initial CT urogram revealed a 4.8cm mass in the proximal right ureter causing moderate hydronephrosis. Further staging demonstrated multiple enlarged retroperitoneal nodes (largest 3.2cm) and bilobar liver metastases (dominant lesion 5.6cm in segment 7). Ureteroscopic biopsy confirmed high-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Molecular profiling has identified a TSC2 mutation which may have therapeutic implications.

He is managing reasonably well with WHO performance status 1. His main symptoms are intermittent right flank pain, controlled with regular paracetamol and occasional tramadol. He has developed mild peripheral edema but maintains good urine output. Blood tests show stable renal function with creatinine 132 μmol/L.

On examination today, there is mild right flank tenderness but no palpable mass. Mild bilateral ankle edema noted. Cardiorespiratory examination unremarkable.

	Further investigations
	Baseline cardiac echo requested
GFR measurement booked
CT chest/abdomen/pelvis in 6 weeks

	Medication prescribed
	Panadol Osteo 665mg - two tablets three times daily
Tramadol 50mg - one to two tablets when required

	Follow up
	Next oncology follow up will be in 2 weeks with blood results
Urology review arranged with Mr [redacted name] regarding nephrostomy consideration

	Required GP actions
	Weekly blood pressure monitoring
Renal function check in 1 week

	Summary of information given to the patient
	We have discussed the diagnosis and prognosis at length. I have explained the role of platinum-based combination chemotherapy as first-line treatment, pending cardiac assessment and formal GFR measurement. We have also discussed the potential relevance of the TSC2 mutation for future targeted therapy options.
